chapter.title: Working With QSOs
chapter.para: The majority of HamQSLer users make use of a QSO logging program; logging programs vary in functionality from simple, basically equivalent to a computerized paper log, up to complex programs that track awards, monitor and control transmitters and receivers, interact with digital modems, and communicate with electronic QSLing services such as Logbook of the World and eQSL. The one common component that exists in all modern logging programs is the ability to exchange data with other programs using Amateur Data Interchange Format (ADIF).

The ADIF standard has existed for many years, and has gone through many changes over that time. The standard is very flexible in that it specifies the various fields that can be contained in a QSO record, but does not mandate that all or even a specific subset of the fields is required in every record. The one requirement that ADIF makes for any program that claims compatibility with any version of the standard is that it must accept as input ADIF files that were generated to any version of the ADIF standard that preceeds the standard that the receiving program claims compatibility with.

caution.para: HamQSLer attempts to follow the latest available version of the ADIF standard but in a few places it may not be able to support esoteric features. In general, this does not cause a problem because HamQSLer is only interested in a few of the fields that appear in QSO records in an ADIF file. Users may make use of macros to access other fields.

HamQSLer validates QSO records to ensure that they contain at least a minimum set of data: start date and time for the QSO, frequency or band used, mode and/or submode used for the QSO, and the callsign of the station contacted. Validity checking is performed on each field within a QSO. For example, if a frequency is specified, it must be within the ADIF specified ham bands, and the callsign must be valid. Full information on the checking that HamQSLer does to each QSO record being input is provided in Appendix D.

chapter.para: A number of users may still keep paper logs. HamQSLer provides a dialog for manually inputting QSOs one at a time. This facility may be used as the only means of inputting QSOs, or may be used in addition to loading QSO data from ADIF files.
This chapter discusses importing QSO data from ADIF files, inputting QSOs using the input dialog, sorting the QSOs and selecting QSOs to be printed on QSL cards.

section.title: Loading and Saving QSOs
section.para: In order to work with QSOs, including loading and saving them, the QSOs tab in the main window of the program must be selected. When the QSOs tab is selected, the QSOs dropdown menu becomes active, along with the menu items that are valid at that time. The menu items are:

listitem.para: Input QSOs... - this opens an input QSO dialog for entering QSOs manually.
Import QSOs... - this opens an Open File dialog to select an ADIF file to import QSOs from. Any QSOs which may have already been loaded into HamQSLer are removed before the new QSOs are loaded.
Add QSOs... - this opens an Open File dialog to select an ADIF file to import QSOs from. These QSOs are added to any QSOs that may already be loaded into the program.
Clear QSOs - this deletes any QSOs that are loaded into the program.
Export QSOs... - this opens a File Save dialog to save the loaded QSOs to an ADIF file.

section.para: Each of these menu items is discussed below.

section.title: Inputting QSOs
section.para: QSOs may be input manually by selecting the Input QSOs... menu item. Selecting this menu item opens the Input QSO dialog as shown in the image below.
The dialog contains a number of text boxes and dropdown boxes that allow the user to enter data about a QSO. This dialog allows entry of only those fields that are used normally by HamQSLer.

tip.para: If additional QSO fields are required, then the user should use an appropriate QSO logging program, then export the QSOs to an ADIF file, and import that file into HamQSLer.

section.para: The callsign, manager, start date, start time, and frequency fields are standard text boxes. All of the standard text editing methods apply to these fields.
Modes are selected from the mode dropdown box. A mode may be selected by:

listitem.para: Clicking the dropdown box. This opens the list of modes; a mode may be selected by clicking on it, or by pressing the up and down arrow keys to highlight a mode, and then pressing the Enter key. Instead of selecting a mode with the mouse or the up and down arrow keys, you may enter the mode using the alphabetic and numeric keys on the keyboard. You should continue to enter keys until the desired mode is highlighted, then press Enter to select the mode. As an alternative to entering the mode by spelling it out, the user may press the first letter of the mode multiple times. This will cycle through all modes that begin with that letter.

Moving focus to the dropdown box by tabbing to it, then using the up and down arrow keys on the keyboard to highlight the mode, and pressing the Enter key to select it. The dropdown box does not open, but the selected mode changes with each press of the up or down arrow keys. Instead of moving through the modes using the arrow keys, you may enter the mode using the alphabetic and numeric keys on the keyboard. As each key is pressed, the mode that most closely matches the entered keys is selected. For example, pressing "C" will select the first mode beginning with "C". If you then press "L", CLO is selected because it is the first mode that begins with "CL". If you press the same letter several times, then the selection will cycle through all of the modes that begin with that letter.

section.para: Once a mode has been selected, the submode combo box is loaded with the list of submodes that correspond to the selected mode. The submode may be selected using any of the methods outlined above for selecting a mode.
Not all possible submodes for each mode are enumerated in the submode combo box, only the common ones. This combo box is editable; you may enter a different value using the keyboard.

caution.para: If you enter a submode using the keyboard, then export the QSOs to an ADIF file and import the file into another program, the receiving program may not accept the submode. The ADIF standard does not specify that any program must accept all submode values; how that program handles submode values not enumerated in the standard is up to the program's author.

section.para: The band dropdown box contains a list of all valid amateur radio bands. A band may be selected by using any of the methods outlined above for selecting an item from the mode dropdown.

The QSL Rcvd and Sent fields are preloaded with the default value ('No") as defined in the ADIF standard. The Sent Via field is set to "Bureau" because that is the value that is assumed by HamQSLer if one of the other values is not selected. All valid values for these three fields are loaded in the dropdown lists. You may select any of the values in the dropdown boxes using the instructions provided for selecting a mode, above.
The values in the dropdown boxes have the following meanings (defined in ADIF).

row.entry: An incoming QSL card has been received.
An incoming QSL card has not been received.
The logging station (you) has requested a QSL card.
DXCC award credit has been granted for this QSO because you submitted a card to the ARRL for this QSO and that card has been verified by the ARRL.
An outgoing QSL card has been sent.
Do not send an outgoing QSL card.
The contacted station has requested a QSL card.
An outgoing QSL card has been selected to be sent.

table.title: QSL Sent Via Values and Meanings

row.entry: An outgoing QSL card should be, or has been, sent via the bureau.
An outgoing QSL card should be, or has been, sent direct to the contacted station or his manager.
The QSO should be, or has been, uploaded to an online service.

section.para: The QSL Rcvd and QSL Sent values also have an effect on the values printed in the QSL column in the QsosBox. See

As a minimum, the callsign, start date, start time, mode, and band or frequency values must be entered in this dialog. Once valid values have been entered in these boxes, the Add+ and OK buttons are enabled to allow the QSO to be added to the QSOs view.

The Add+ button validates the contents of the QSO fields, then adds the QSO to the list of QSOs in the QSOs view, and deletes the contents of all boxes in the dialog to prepare for entry of the next QSO. The OK button validates the contents of the QSO fields, then adds the QSO to the list of QSOs in the QSOs view and closes the Input QSO dialog. The Cancel button closes the dialog without adding an entered QSO into the QSOs view.

section.title: Validating a QSO Input via the Input QSO Dialog
section.para: In the image of the Input QSO dialog, several of the text boxes are outlined in red. See Error Handling and Logging for a discussion of input validation and the reason that these text boxes are outlined.
The value entered into the callsign text box must be a valid callsign. A callsign is determined to be valid if it matches one of the following:

listitem.para: One or two letters followed by one or more numbers followed by one or more letters.
A single number followed by one or two letters followed by one or more numbers followed by one or more letters.

A callsign that do not match the formats listed above. A list of valid non-standard callsigns is maintained and read by the program. A non-standard callsign must be in the list to be considered valid. Some examples of valid non-standard callsigns are BX100, LM9L40Y, and OEH20.

Any non-standard callsign that is shown in the ARRL DX bulletin, issued weekly, is added to the list. HamQSLer users may request that a callsign be added to the list by filing an enhancement issue. See the website for instructions.

section.para: The callsign may have a leading qualifier followed by "/" and one or more trailing qualifiers, with each trailing qualifier preceeded by "/". A leading qualifier is always a country or territory identifier. The trailing qualifier is typically an indicator about the operation, such as /M for mobile, /MM for maritime mobile, /AM for aeronautical mobile, /P for portable, /QRP for QRP, and so forth. For United States / Canada reciprocal operations, the country/territory identifier is appended to the callsign and placed before other trailing qualifiers. HamQSLer only checks the callsign for validity, and not the leading and trailing qualifiers.
The manager text box must either be empty, or contain a valid callsign with no leading or trailing qualifiers.
The start date must be exactly 8 digits long, be of the form YYYYMMDD and be a date between 19300101 and today.
The start time must be either 4 digits of the form HHMM, or 6 digits of the form HHMMSS. The time must be between 0000 and 2359 or between 000000 and 235959.

The signal report field accepts any text up to three characters in length. The normal values here are RS for analog voice modes, RST for CW and similar modes, RSQ for most digital modes, and dB for JT65 and similar modes.

caution.para: No validation is performed on the signal report. If you enter text that is not representative of "standard" values, the report may not be understood by your card's recipient.

section.para: The band and frequency boxes work together, and at least one of these boxes must contain a value.
A frequency may be entered into the frequency text box. The frequency must be entered in MHz, and must be within the frequency limits of an ADIF defined band.

If a band is selected and then a frequency is entered, the frequency is checked to ensure that it is within the limits of the selected band. If a frequency is entered first and then a band is selected, the band is checked to ensure that the frequency is within that band. If the frequency is not within the selected band, then the second value entered is shown as being in error.
The QSL statuses are optional. No validation is performed on these fields.

section.title: Importing QSOs
section.para: The Import QSOs... menu item opens the default ADIF files folder in a File Open dialog to allow the user to select an ADIF file to load QSOs from. The default ADIF files folder is set in user preferences. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for more information on setting this default folder.

ADIF files have the file extension .adi. Opening a file deletes any QSOs that had previously been loaded and loads the QSOs contained in the file into HamQSLer. The QSOs are then displayed in the QSOs View in the QSOs tab. The image below shows the main window and QSOs tab when the sample.adi file, located in the Samples subdirectory, is loaded.

figure.title: Main Program Window With Sample QSOs loaded

section.para: The contents of the QSOs View, the sort panel and the selection panel are discussed in another section below.

caution.para: Do not import or add ADIF files with a large number of QSOs. The greater the number of QSOs, the longer loading, sorting and displaying the QSOs takes. ADIF files with a very large number of QSOs take an excessive amount of time to display.

section.title: Adding QSOs
section.para: The Add QSOs... menu item opens the default ADIF files folder in a File Open dialog to allow the user to select an ADIF file to load QSOs from. The default ADIF files folder is set in the user preferences. See the Setting User Preferences chapter for more information on this option.

The QSOs in the ADIF file are added to any QSOs that were previously loaded into the program. Once the QSOs have been loaded, any duplicated QSOs are deleted, and then the QSOs are sorted according the sort order selected in the sort panel.

caution.para: Do not import or add ADIF files with a large number of QSOs. The greater the number of QSOs, the longer loading, sorting and displaying the QSOs takes. ADIF files with a very large number of QSOs take an excessive amount of time to display.

section.title: Clear QSOs
section.para: The Clear QSOs menu item deletes all QSOs that were loaded into HamQSLer.

section.title: Exporting QSOs
section.para: The Export QSOs... menu item opens the default ADIF files folder in a File Save dialog. This allows the user to save, to an ADIF file, any QSOs that are loaded in the program. Normally the user would only want to do this if he input one or more QSOs using the QSO input dialog, or if he changed the manager field in the QSOs view.

section.title: Reloading ADIF Files on Program Startup
section.para: The Reload ADIF File on Startup setting in user preferences determines whether the ADIF files that were loaded before HamQSLer was last terminated are reloaded when the program restarts. See Setting User Preferences for more information on this setting. The list of ADIF files to be reloaded is maintained in the user preferences file.
The following table describes what ADIF files are saved to be reloaded based on the actions related to ADIF files.

table.title: ADIF File List For Reloading - Menu Items and Actions

row.entry: The reload list is cleared, and the name of the ADIF file being imported is added to the list.
The name of the ADIF file being added is added to the list.
The reload list is cleared and the name of the ADIF file that is saved is added to the list.

caution.para: The list of files to be reloaded is initialized to an empty list when the Reload ADIF Files on Startup setting is changed. Therefore, only the actions performed after the setting is set are valid. For example, if you set the Reload ADIF Files on Startup setting after loading an ADIF file, that file will not be reloaded the next time the program starts.

section.title: The QSOs Panel

figure.title: Main Program Window With Sample QSOs loaded

section.para: The image above shows the main program window with the QSOs tab selected immediately after the sample QSOs are loaded. The panel on the left is the QSOs panel, which contains a table of some of the fields for each QSO. The following table contains a list of the columns in the panel and their contents or meaning.

row.entry: A checkbox indicating whether this QSO will be included when cards are printed.
The call sign of the other station's QSL manager.
The start date of the QSO.
The start time of the QSO.
The band that the QSO occurred on, or the band that you transmitted on.
The frequency that the other station used for the QSO.
The mode used for the QSO.
The submode used for the QSO.
The signal report you sent to the other station.
Value corresponding to the ADIF QSL_SENT field. See the QSL Sent Values and Meanings table in the Inputting QSOs section, above.
Value corresponding to the ADIF QSL_RCVD field. See the QSL Rcvd Values and Meanings table in the Input QSOs section, above.
Value indicates whether the QSL card containing this QSO should be sent via the Bureau or Direct. See the QSL Sent Via Values and Meanings table in the Input QSOs section, above.

section.para: Values in only the Include and Manager columns are editable. Including QSOs when printing cards is discussed in the Selecting QSOs for Printing section. The Manager fields are standard text box fields. All of the standard text editing features are included.
The QSOs are sorted in one of three ways. This is discussed in the Sorting QSOs section.

section.title: Sorting QSOs
section.para: The image below provides a larger view of the Sort panel in the QSOs properties panel.
With the Date/Time radio button selected, the QSOs are sorted by date and then by time. This is the default sort order (the order in which the QSOs are sorted when QSOs are first loaded).
Selecting the Call radio button sorts the QSOs by Manager call sign if one is included in the QSO, then by the other station's call sign, and then by date and time.

Selecting the Bureau radio button sorts the QSOs by the bureau for the Manager if a Manager is included in the QSO or the bureau for the other station if a Manager is not included, then by the Manager callsign, the other station's callsign, and then by date and time. The QSOs whose Manager (or call sign field) has a valid bureau are sorted first in the list, then the QSOs for which there is no bureau are placed after the bureau QSOs. QSOs whose QSL_SENT_VIA ADIF field is set to D (Direct) also have their Send Via value set to Direct and are therefore sorted with other Direct QSOs.

The QSOs are sorted as soon as a radio button is selected. The Sort button is enabled only when a new QSO is input using the Input QSOs dialog box. When entering QSOs manually, the QSOs are added the bottom of the displayed QSOs. The Sort button must be clicked to properly sort the QSOs in that case.

section.title: Selecting QSOs for Printing
section.para: When you first input, import, or add QSOs, all QSOs are selected. There are many ways to select QSOs for printing:

listitem.para: Using filters contained in the filter tabs. You may select QSOs by band, mode, QSL statuses and by date and time ranges.
Selecting and deselecting individual QSOs in the QSOs panel.
Selecting and deselecting multiple QSOs in the QSOs panel.

section.para: Each of these methods is discussed in the subsections below.

section.title: Filtering QSOs for Printing
section.para: QSOs may be filtered by band, mode, QSL statuses, and by date and time range using the filters in the filters tabs. The image below shows the filters tabs with the band tab selected. Each of the filters is discussed in the subsections which follow.

caution.para: The settings in the four filter tabs work together to determine whether a QSO will be included for printing or not. Even though the individual filter sections state that you can include all QSOs that match a particular filter by checking that filter, some QSOs may not be included because other filters that affect these QSOs have been unchecked.

section.title: Filtering QSOs by Band
section.para: The Band filter tab contains a checkbox for each band that is included in at least one of the QSOs that is loaded. The image above shows the Band tab as it would be with the sample.adi file in the Samples directory loaded.
Check a band checkbox to include all QSOs made in that band when printing cards. Uncheck a band checkbox to not include those QSOs.

tip.para: You may override the Include checkbox for individual QSOs after this filter has been set. See the Manually Selecting QSOs section for more information.

section.title: Filtering QSOs by Mode
section.para: The Mode filter tab contains a checkbox for each mode that is included in at least one of the QSOs that is loaded. The image below shows the Mode tab as it would be with the sample.adi file in the Samples directory loaded.
Check a mode checkbox to include all QSOs made in that mode when printing cards. Uncheck a mode checkbox to not include those QSOs.

tip.para: You may override the Include checkbox for individual QSOs after this filter has been set. See the Manually Selecting QSOs section for more information.

section.title: Filtering QSOs by QSL Statuses
section.para: The QSL Status filter tab contains panels for QSL received status, QSL sent status and send via status. Each panel contains a checkbox for each status that is included in at least one loaded QSO. The image below shows the QSL Status tab as it would be with the sample.adi file in the Samples directory loaded.
Check a status checkbox to include all QSOs containing that status when printing cards. Uncheck a status checkbox to not include those QSOs.

tip.para: You may override the Include checkbox for individual QSOs after this filter has been set. See the Manually Selecting QSOs section for more information.

section.title: Filtering QSOs by Date and Time
section.para: The Date/Time filter tab contains a start date and time and an end date and time as well as a Reset button. The image below shows the Date/Time filter tab as it would be immediately after loading the sample.adi file located in the Samples directory.

When QSOs are first loaded, the values in the start date and time text boxes correspond to date and time of the earliest QSO that is loaded. The values in the end date and time text boxes correspond to the date and time of the latest QSO that is loaded.
To select QSOs over a narrower date and time range, change the dates and times to the range that you want. The Include checkbox for all QSOs that are outside this range will be unchecked.
Click the Reset button to reset the start and end dates and times to the earliest and latest dates and times for the loaded QSOs.

caution.para: The entered dates and times must be between 19300101 and the current date and time.

tip.para: You may override the Include checkbox for individual QSOs after this filter has been set. See the Manually Selecting QSOs section for more information.

section.title: Manually Selecting QSOs For Printing
section.para: Individual QSOs may be selected or deselected for printing by checking or unchecking the checkbox in the Include column corresponding to the QSO that you want to include or not include.

The Include status of multiple QSOs may be set by first selecting all of the QSOs whose status you want to change, and then checking or unchecking the Include checkbox for one of the selected QSOs. To select a number of QSOs, you must start by selecting one QSO. Do this by clicking anywhere in the QSO in the QSOs panel except in the Include checkbox or the Manager text box. The QSO will be highlighted. The image below shows the QSO with CG3JNO selected.

To select additional QSOs, press and hold the Ctrl key, then click on each QSO that you want to select. Each selected QSO will be highlighted. When you have selected all of the wanted QSOs, release the Ctrl button.

To select a range of QSOs, select the first QSO in the range. Press and hold the Shift key and click on the last QSO in the range that you want to select, then release the Shift key. All QSOs in the range will be highlighted. You may then select additional QSOs by pressing the Ctrl key before clicking on those QSOs.
To deselect a QSO, press and hold the Ctrl key and click on the QSO that you want to deselect. Release the Ctrl key.

You may select all QSOs by first clicking anywhere within the QSOs panel and then pressing the Ctrl and A keys on the keyboard or by selecting the Select All QSOs menu item in the Select dropdown menu. You may deselect all selected QSOs by selecting the Deselect All QSOs menu item in the Select dropdown menu.

caution.para: If you change any of the filters after you have manually selected QSOs, all of your manual selections are lost. You will have to set them again.

section.para: To change the Include checkboxes for all selected QSOs, check or uncheck the Include checkbox for one of the selected QSOs. The Include checkboxes for all selected QSOs will be changed to match the new state and the QSOs will be deselected.

caution.para: If the Include checkboxes for some of the selected QSOs are checked and some are unchecked, the final state will match the toggled state of the checkbox that you click. That is, if the checkbox that you clicked was checked when you clicked it, then the checkboxes for all selected QSOs will be unchecked.

section.para: You may check all Include checkboxes by selecting the Include All QSOs menu item in the QSOs dropdown menu, and you may uncheck all Include checkboxes by selecting the Exclude All QSOs menu item in the QSOs dropdown menu.
